structure.name: Event Structure
structure.description:
1. The theme for this year,s competition is Smart City.
  2. Students can use any kit with any type of microcontroller (Arduino UNO, Arduino Nano, Arduino Mega etc.)
  3. Members of a team may be from the same school or different
  4. Any number of teams can participate from one school
  5. For students in grades II to XII
  6. There are 2 rounds for this zonal competition

structure.name: 1st Round:
structure.description: The first round will be an online round and the participants should build the robot under the title of smart city and post it on YouTube. Shortlisted participants will be invited to the 2nd round of this zonal competition.

structure.name: 2nd Round:
structure.description:
The second round will be conducted at the CoE Pune venue for demonstration.
The Robotics Project implemented with the most creative and innovative ideas will have a high chance of winning.
Bonus points would be awarded for the Robotics Project Presentation.

structure.name: Project Submission Guidelines for Round 1:
structure.description:
1. The video should not be longer than 5 mins
  2. The video should clearly demonstrate the functioning of the robotics project
  3. The video should be a self-shot one. Usage of online & readymade videos is not allowed.
  4. The video should be uploaded to YouTube with the below format
  5. Video Title: Playto Labs - National Robotics Competition - {Project Name} by {Student Name}
  6. Video Format: Introduction to team members or self, Project Explanation & Project Demonstration
  7. Video Description: Add the details of the project & Team Members names (if any)
  8. Note: Only YouTube video links will be accepted for the online submission. You can make the video as unlisted if you don't want the video to be public

structure.name: Important Dates:
structure.description:
Last date for online submission: on or before 11:59 PM, 24 Oct'23
Announcement of shortlisted students for CoE Pune Zonal: 25 Oct'23
Announcement of shortlisted students for CoE Pune Zonal: 25 Oct'23

structure.description: Take-off consists of the participants using a pressure launcher to launch a water bottle rocket into the air. Participants have to construct their own water bottle rocket of a design of their choice. The event comprises three rounds which will be as follows-

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Maximum 3 per team.

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹49/- per person

structure.name: Round 1:
structure.description: The ground will be divided into six concentric zones from the launcher for this round. Further, the ground will be divided into 3 sectors, with each sector containing the mentioned 6 scoring zones. From the launching point, the participant will have to use the launcher to launch the water bottle rocket. The participants will have to choose one of the three sectors towards which they will be launching their rocket. The participant will be given points according to the area in which the rocket lands. If the rocket does not land in the sector chosen by the participant, no points will be awarded. The area and the points that the area holds will be visible during the event. This round will give 3 attempts to each team. The total score of the 3 attempts will be considered.

structure.name: Round 2:
structure.description: For this round, a target will be declared. Points will be awarded based on the distance between the rocket and the target. The point at which the rocket touches the ground for the first time will be considered, and subsequent bounces/sliding will not be considered.

structure.name: Round 3:
structure.description: In this round, the participants will have to attach a deployable parachute to the rocket using materials and design of their choice. Points will be awarded based on the time for which the rocket stays in the air after parachute deployment.

rules: Participants will be required to bring their college ID cards.
Participants will have to bring their own rockets made of plastic bottles and water. The launcher and pump will be provided by the organizing team of the event.
Only the launcher provided by the organizing team must be used. Use of other launchers or hand-based launchers is not permitted.
In Round 1, if the rocket falls on the boundary of two zones, then the points of the zone with higher points will be counted.
Points will be counted only for the time of flight before the rocket touches the ground for the first time.
In Round 3, participants will be disqualified in case the parachute doesn't open.
The pump pressure can only be applied in the given range as specified by the organizing team.

events.name: CONTRAPTION
events.description: A trial of your ability to manipulate energies as you transform one mechanical motion into another.
events.long_description: Conservation of energy and mass are two rules which govern the universe. This event is designed towards converting energy from one form to another and driving a series of events that will ultimately carry out the given task. The more complicated the contraption and the more forms of energy used, the higher the points earned.
note: If number of participants are less than 20 then only 2 winners will be selected.
If number of participants are less than 5 then only 1 winner will be selected.
If number of participants are less than or equal to 3 then event will be cancelled.
No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.
Prize money is subject to change.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Minimum 4 and Maximum 5 per team.

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹ 199/- per team

structure.name: Round 1:
structure.description: The first round consists of abstract submission (soft copy) for which the problem statement will be released to all

structure.name: Round 2:
structure.description: Depending on the abstract, the top 6 teams will be short-listed for Round 2 which will be the qualification round. All the top 6 teams are expected to get 4 copies of the printed abstract for the event, clearly mentioning steps and chart, which shows all Energy conversions

structure.name: Elimination Criteria
structure.description:
Qualification for Round 2 is on the basis of:
1. Closeness/alignment with this year's theme.
2. Maximum conservation of energy.
3. Number of energy conversions - (more the conversions, better it is!).
4. Use of sustainable materials.

rules: The minimum and maximum time for contraption are 2 minutes and 6 minutes respectively. After 6 minutes, 30 Points per minute will be deducted per minute from the total score.

The contraption setup is to be developed in an area with dimensions 15ft X 20ft, and the height must not cross 5ft; (you may have a smaller setup not less than 5ft by 5ft) the setup should fit in an imaginary box of the above-mentioned dimensions.
The participants are requested to prevent spillage of any kind of fluid and should take precautionary measures in case of any such step involved.
No harmful explosives that may cause harm to the surroundings are to be included in the making of the contraption.

Two hand touches are allowed without deduction of points. Before the 3rd hand touch, the team would be given choice to go for 3rd hand touch or to go for the second trial. For 3rd, 4th and 5th hand touch, 30, 60, and 120 points will be deducted respectively from the total score.

If the team decides to go for the second attempt, 50 points will be deducted initially, and 2 hand touches will be allowed further with a deduction of 50 and 80 points, respectively. The team will be disqualified if they exceed the permissible number of hand touches (5 for attempt 1; and 2 for attempt 2) in the respective trial.
Sufficient set-up time will be given and 1 hour will be given for each team for first attempt and second attempt of the model respectively. Only 2   attempts are allowed.
No alteration (without prior notice) in any step will be allowed during the trial of the contraption.
Students should carry proof of identity issued by their institution.
The same person cannot be a member of more than one team. All teams involving a common person as a participant will be disqualified.
Participants are required to report at (TIME - to be DECIDED).
Participants should take due safety measures in their models.
Rules are subject to change without prior intimation. Participants are requested to check the MindSpark'23 website (www.mind-spark.org) regularly for updates.
All decisions of Judges, Event Heads, and Organizers will be final and binding to all participants. No arguments shall be entertained.
Bring special tools of your own if you think they are important for the building of your Contraption.
Extension boards for any required power supply will be provided by the organising committee.
Minimum number of steps is 4.

q: I am participating in another event in MindSpark. Can I still register for this event?
Is on-spot participation allowed?
Who can participate in the event?
What is the team structure?
What should I bring for the event?
Is this an open-book event?
Is the use of Internet allowed?
Can I register on the day of the event?
a: You can participate in any event in MindSpark, provided you can manage your own schedule.
Yes. On-spot participation is allowed.
Any college (UG)* student. You may be asked to present a valid ID card and the registration receipt.

A team must consist of 2 members. Members can be from same or different institutions. However, no person may be a part of multiple teams for the same event. This event will be open for all undergraduate students of the recognized universities and colleges.

While College ID Cards and receipt of registration are compulsory, you may carry a pen/pencil, if you wish to work out a rough plan for round 2. Rough sheets will be provided upon request, however, participants cannot bring any rough book with them.
It is not an open book event. Although, participants within a team are allowed to help each other in solving the problem, and in multiple choice questions. No team is allowed to help any other team.
No, the use of Internet is not allowed for round 2, although Internet access will be provided only for round 1.

Registrations are open on the event day. However, if the number of teams exceed the limit set by us, on-the-spot registrations may be closed. It is highly recommended that registration be done in advance to avoid any such incidences on the day of the event.

events.name: TECH DE BAIT
events.description: It is better to debate a question without settling it than to settle a question without debating it.
events.long_description:
Debate is a process that involves formal discourse on a particular topic, often including a moderator and audience.
Through this, students get the opportunity to work in a collaborative and cooperative group setting & develop their communication and listening skills. This will also help students learn through friendly competition, examine controversial topics and strengthen skills in the areas of leadership, interpersonal influence, team building, group problem-solving, and oral presentation.
note: If number of participants are less than 20 then only 2 winners will be selected.
If number of participants are less than 5 then only 1 winner will be selected.
If number of participants are less than or equal to 3 then event will be cancelled.
No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.
Prize money is subject to change.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: 2 members per team (Allotted on the spot unless preferences are given).

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹59 per person

structure.name: Details
structure.description:
1. Tech-related topics to be released a week prior to competition. Up to 3 motions can be released.
2. Each student can do readings relevant to all 3 topics as preparation prior to event.
3. On the day of the competition, students will be paired into groups of 2. Each member will be allotted to be for or against the motion on the spot and will be assigned any one of the 3 topics that were previously declared.
4. Each pair will get 10 minutes of preparation time and will then engage in a debate on the allocated topic.
5. Max speech time of each pair: 15 mins.
6. Time allotted for questioning opponent after respective speeches: 1.5 mins.
7. In case of a significantly large number of participants, multiple rooms can be conducted simultaneously.
8. Audience members can raise their hand to ask questions during the last 2 minutes of each of the speaker's speeches.

structure.name: Elimination Criteria
structure.description:
Each 1 v 1 pairing will be judged on the following aspects
(In order of significance):
1. Content and logic of arguments.
2. Structure of speech
3. Response to question asked by opponent + Question asked to opponent
4. Fluency of speech
Depending on the cumulative score, participants with the highest overall scores will be declared as winners.
(Similar criteria for 2v2 in the first round)

structure.name: Winning Criteria
structure.description:
There will be 2 winners and 1 for Best Question.
Best Question Criteria:
1. How it attacks the basis of the speaker's argument.

structure.name: Round 1:
structure.description: This round will consist of a test paper consisting of indefinite and definite integrals; a fixed amount of time will be given to every student to take the test. The student will be expected to produce the answers to the given integrals correctly by using any method or technique she/he finds suitable. Marks will only be given to the student if the integral is exactly correct, and no other scenario would be considered. Remaining details of the test will be declared on the day of the event. The top 16 students will be selected from this round and will be proceeding to the final round.

structure.name: Round 2:
structure.description: This is the round where your nerve and mettle will be tested. This is the face-off round. In this round top 16 student will be pitched against each other. It will be a one-on-one match. In a match, a single integral would be announced by the integration master and the person who solves it t first would get a point. In such a way 5 integrals would be asked in a single match. The student who scores more points would win that match. In this manner, the top 8 students will be selected, and they will go against each other. The format of the match will be same as above. Out of the top 8 four will be selected for the semi-finals and the top four will go against each other to get a place in the finals. In the final showdown between the two finalists, the integration master would announce seven integrals out of which the finalist who scores more points would win. The integrals in this round would be both indefinite and definite. The winner of the final match would be crowned as the grand integrator and will be awarded the grand prize.

structure.name: Elimination Criteria:
structure.description:
1. 16 people for the preliminary round (5 integrals will be given to everyone)
2. 8 people will be selected out of 16 people and each participant will be assigned some other participant with whom they will compete for the second round.
3. Second round will be between 8 people who will be winners of first round.
4. Third round will be between 4 people who will be winners of second round.
5. Fourth round is final between two people (7 integrals will be given to each participant). Third place match will also be conducted.

details.description: Dive in the world of robots. Participate in exciting robot events

events.name: BOT WRESTLING
events.description: The territory is marked and your aim is simple. Stay in the ring, push your opponents out and the trophy is yours.
events.long_description: Bot Wrestling is basically a competition of two wired or wireless operated robots competing in an attempt to push the opponent out of the arena. These robots must be remote operated.
note: No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Max 4 participants per team

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹ 249 per team.

structure.name: Event Structure
structure.description: The arena consists of one ring which is blue surrounded by a Red Zone. The aim of the robots is to push the opposition robot out of the blue zone. Robots gains points for pushing the opposition robot in the red zone. Points are deducted from the teams score if it enters the red zone on its own. The team that successfully completely pushes the opposition robot in the red zone will win the round.

structure.name: Qualifier Round
structure.description:
1. Qualifier round will be held prior to the knockout round. The duration of the qualifying round will be 3 minutes.
  2. In each match, two teams will compete against each other at a time try to earn maximum points.
  3. The teams will be ranked according to their points.
  4. Top 8 teams will qualify for the finals. Other than this, the performance in the qualifier round is of no significance to the contest.

structure.name: Knockout Round
structure.description:
1. Two teams will compete against each other like in the qualifier one.
  2. Each round will have a duration of 3 minute. The team which wins two rounds first will be declared the winner of the match.
  3. The team that pushes the opposition robot out of the arena (i.e. out of the blue zone) is declared as the winner of that round.
  4. The scoring pattern will be uniform throughout and the scores will be considered only in case of a tie i.e. if no team is able to push the opponent's robot out of the arena in that round.
  5. In case of a tie in a round (i.e. none of the team's robot is able to push the opposition robot out of the arena), the winner will be decided by the points earned by each team in that round.
  6. In case of a tie in the match, the winner of the match will be decided by a tiebreaker.

structure.name: Tasks
structure.description:
1. Teams must build a robot that can be wirelessly controlled using a controller. No compulsion for wired or wireless.
  2. The aim of the robot is to push the robot of the opposite team out of the way. The team that does so wins the match.

structure.name: Arena
structure.description:
1. The arena will be square in shape of side 2400 mm.
  2. The main arena will be a circular in shape with a maximum diameter 2200 mm.
  3. The inner circular area is blue in color and is called the “Blue Zone” while the outer area is red in color and is called the “Red Zone”.
  4. A center white line of 30 mm width divides the arena into two equal halves.
  5. There are white squares of 300 mm x 300 mm on the opposite sides of this line that indicate the starting zones of the two competing teams.
  6. The arena will be made up of wood and the markings on it including all the zones will be drawn using paint.

structure.name: Machine Specification
structure.description:
1. The machine should fit in a square of 300mm x 300mm. There is no height limit.
  2. The combined weight of the robot and the remote must not exceed 5 kg.
  3. If the team is using a laptop or a mobile phone for controlling the robot then its weight is not included in the above.
  4. The robot must be stable and must stand on its own at the beginning of the run when put in the starting point. Robots not fulfilling this criterion will be disqualified.
  5. During the match, the robot can expand itself provided it does not damage the arena in anyway. However, the machine should not leave anything behind while competing. The machine should not scratch, damage or destroy the arena or accompanying parts of arena.
  6. The machine should not shoot anything at the opponent's robot.
  7. Any robot found damaging the arena will be immediately disqualified. The final decision is at the discretion of the organizers.
  8. Readymade (market sold) robot with or without modifications will not be allowed in the competition.

structure.name: Power Supply
structure.description:
1. Machine must be completely self-contained and should receive no outside assistance. It should not use an energy source employing a combustion process.
  2. Machine should have an on-board power supply. No external power supply is allowed.
  3. Voltage on the machine at any point should not exceed 12 V DC.

structure.name: Points
structure.description:
1. One match shall consist of 3 rounds, within a total time of 3 minutes, unless extended by the judges.
  2. Each team earns 20 points for pushing the opposition in the red zone.
  3. If a robot goes in the red zone on its own without being pushed by the opponent robot, then 10 points will be deducted from the teams score entering the red zone. No points will be given to the opponent in such a case.
  4. The team who wins two rounds within the time limit, shall win the match. If the time limit is reached, the team who score more points will win.
  5. If time limit is reached and both the team scores equal points, then an extended match may be fought. During extended time, team who scores first will win the match.
  6. The score of teams may be negative.
  7. Judge's decision shall be treated as final and binding to all.
  8. The organizers reserve the rights to change any or all of the above rules as they deem fit.

structure.name: General Rules
structure.description:
1. Any team that is not ready at the time specified will be disqualified from the competition automatically.
  2. The machine will be checked for its safety before each match and will be discarded if found unsafe for other participants and spectators.
  3. Team members will not be allowed to step in the arena. Only organizers are allowed in any situation. The team will be disqualified if any of the team members steps on the arena without the approval of the presiding organizers.
  4. Only one member of the team is allowed to handle and operate the robot.
  5. Participants are not allowed to keep anything inside the arena other than its robot.
  6. No robot is allowed to use any flammable, combustible, explosive or potentially dangerous processes.
  7. Proper protection measures from short-circuiting of batteries are required to be taken by participants for the safety of everyone present at arena.
  8. The time measured by the organizers will be final and will be used for scoring the teams. Time measured by any contestant by any other means is not acceptable for scoring.
  9. In case of any disputes/discrepancies, the organizers' decision will be final and binding. The organizers reserve the rights to change any or all of the above rules as they deem fit. Change in rules, if any, will be highlighted on the website and notified to the registered teams.

structure.name: Hand Touch
structure.description:
1. No hand touches are allowed in between the matches unless both the operators of the respective robots want a restart.
  2. If a restart is taken, then both the robots will be placed back in their respective starting zones.
  3. Even if a participant takes a hand touch, the clock will keep running and will not be reset as the robots start again from the starting points.

structure.name: Note
structure.description:
1. No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
  2. Registration fee is non-refundable.
  3. Prize Money is subject to change.

events.long_description: This event involves the manufacturing, testing, and racing of a wireless/wired remote- controlled, 2-4 wheeled robot

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Min 2 and Max 4 participants per team

structure.name: Round 1 : Qualification Round
structure.description:
Time trials will make up this round. Each team will be given a chance. The time will be recorded.The first 16 teams will be chosen for the subsequent round.
Track for the Round 1 is given below.
Checkpoints will be declared during the game time.

structure.name: Round 2: Elimination Round
structure.description:
The top 16 teams from the first round will be selected for this round. A modified track shall be disclosed at the time of the event. All teams will be given 15 minutes to analyse the track.
The team with Rank 1 will have match with team with rank 16, rank 2 team with rank 15 team and so on. In this round, all the 16 teams race with their respective competitors, and the 8 winning teams will be promoted to the next final round.
New Ranking will be given based on the performance in Round 2.

structure.name: Round 3: Finals
structure.description:
1. Final consists of both Individual and one on one matches.
  2. Each team, beginning from Rank 1 will get a chance to challenge any team. Any team can reject a challenge only once, except when the team is being challenged by a team ranked lower than it. If the challenge thrown by a team is rejected, the next ranked team gets the chance to challenge any team. If a challenge is accepted, a time slot will be given to those teams and the match will be conducted.
  3. The four winners from above will have Individual race on the Modified track for the Mega Finals and the top three ranking will be decided.
  4. The team completing the race in least time will be crowned as the 'CHAMPIONS of ROBORACES.'

structure.name: Arena Details
structure.description:
1. The racetrack will be a combination of wedges and inclinations with many hurdles. Participants are advised to use proper motors and tyres to endure the hurdles.
  2. Check points will be provided on the track where the robot can restart, in case of a disturbance.

structure.name: Specification
structure.description:
Battery:
  1. Li-po, Li-ion, or cell batteries can be used in the robot.
  2. Batteries used are to be placed in a protective shield and at the safest place on the robot so that the battery will be safe at the time of an accident.

    3. Robot dimensions:
    1. A robot should fit into a box of dimensions 300 mm x 350 mm x 350 mm (l x b x h) at any time during the race. The external device which is used to control the robot is not included in the dimensions.

      2. Parts that can be directly procured from the market:
      1. Motors.
      2. Tyres and Wheels.

        3. Power supply:
        1. The robot must have an on-board power supply to provide power to any mechanism requiring electric power not exceeding 24 V.

          2. Radio controllers:
          1. In case of wireless controlling, the robot has to be necessarily controlled by a wireless remote-control system.
          2. All Bluetooth modules are applicable.

structure.name: Note
structure.description:
1. No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
  2. Registration fee is non-refundable.
  3. Prize Money is subject to change.

rules: Each team can be comprised of a minimum of two members and a maximum of four members.
Participants must use a remote with a frequency of band spectrum 4 GHz only. No power supply will be given on the track. Bluetooth modules 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 are applicable.

Team members are not permitted to touch either their robots or those of their opponents once the race begins (unless there is a need to lift the robot). The penalty for doing so on invalid grounds is disqualification.
Teams are prohibited from purposefully damaging the robots of the opponent. If found guilty, the concerned team will be disqualified.

If the robot is found unsafe to run on the track, that team will be disqualified from the race. The coordinator's decision will be final and binding to all in this. No damage to the track will be tolerated, and if found guilty, the responsible team will be disqualified.
The robots are not allowed to leave any loose parts or any extra parts on any part of the arena.
Any robot that disintegrates during the race will be disqualified. The vehicle must remain intact throughout the race. Once the race gets started, the participants must complete the race.

The track will have checkpoints at regular intervals. If the robot halts, tumbles, or goes off the arena at any point, one of the team members is allowed to lift it up and place it at the nearest completed checkpoint. However, the timer will still be running in the condition.
People from different institutes can be a part of the same team. However, one person cannot be a member of multiple teams at the same time.
Only undergraduate students may participate.
The judges' and organizers' decisions shall be treated as final and binding to all.

events.name: ROBO FALCONARY
events.description: Would you rather walk or run to victory? Let us make the choice for you. Be part of Robo Falconry and fly towards victory.
events.long_description: In the Drone Races event, different teams can race with various kinds of drones/UAV (Tri/Quadcopter). It is a timed obstacle race. The fastest drone to complete all checkpoints without straying off course wins.
note: No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Max 5 participants per team

structure.name: Entry Fee

structure.name: Track Explanation
structure.description:
The race comprises of
  1. Start Point
  2. 3 hurdles
  3. 1 Loop set of 3 pillars
  4. Finish

structure.name: Specifications
structure.description:
1. Max Weight - 1200 g
  2. Dimension - (200-500 mm diagonal frame length)
  3. Max propellers - 4
  4. Max propeller length - 10 inches.
  5. Commercial drones (Market bought drones) not allowed. 6. FPV (Optional).

structure.name: Competition Rules
structure.description:
1. On the day of the race, all participants must present valid college ID proof to the organizing committee.
  2. Every drone will be given 2 chances to complete the race-track and the best of 2 will be considered. The timer will start at the entry of the first hurdle and will stop at exit from the loop.
  3. If a drone goes ahead without crossing a checkpoint (all obstacles are considered as checkpoints), the next checkpoint will not be considered.
  4. The pilot will be informed by the organizing committee in case of a missed checkpoint, and in this situation, the drone must be placed at the last completed checkpoint and then it can resume the race, but the timer will be on for the duration of the reset.
  5. If the drone goes outside the arena, then it will have to resume from the last checkpoint and timer will be on for that duration.
  6. It will be a timed qualifier in which each team will have 2 attempts to complete the course as quickly as possible. The fastest one wins!

structure.name: Safety Rules
structure.description:
1. The safety of all people nearby while the drone is being flown is to be ensured. If the drone goes out of control, the team controlling the drone will be held accountable for any damage to property or personnel.
  2. Races must proceed in a fair manner. If a team is found to be damaging another team's drone on purpose, the latter will be disqualified.
  3. The drone will be checked before the race. It will only be allowed to race if it is found fit.
  4. After the check, no modifications to the drone will be allowed.
  5. If a team is found to be making modifications to the drone after the checking round, that team will be disqualified. 6. The judge's decision will be final and binding.

structure.name: Practice Rules
structure.description:
1. Each team will be given 20 minutes to practice.

events.name: SEARCH N' DESTROY
events.description: The only road that leads to the first prize is the one that is filled with twists and turns. Maneuver and surge ahead.
events.long_description: Search N Destroy is basically a line-following and maze-solving competition. A track of white lines on black backgrounds and black lines on white backgrounds will be laid out and an autonomous robot must follow that line. The robot must complete a task. The path will have checkpoints. Each checkpoint will earn some points based on the number of checkpoints covered; the time taken to cover these checkpoints as well as the task completed will decide the points earned by the robot. The team which follows the correct path the fastest will be the winner.
note: No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Max 5 participants per team

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹ 249 per team.

structure.name: Arena
structure.description:
1. All dimensions are in mm.
  2. The maximum size of the arena will be 5200 x 4500mm.
  3. The width of the track will be 30mm.
  4. The dimensions of the start zone are 200 x 200mm.
  5. The floor arena shall be made of wood (plywood) and finished by vinyl. Do not assume that the floor provides the necessary amount of friction.
  6. Participants should not assume that the track is always black, as fading may occur.
  7. The track will have discontinuities at some.
  8. All the possible checkpoints are marked as black stripes perpendicular to the track having the dimensions of 90 x 30 mm. The checkpoints are CP1, CP2 & CP3, CP4 & CP5.
  9. The dimensions of the arena will be accurate to within 5%, or 20mm.
  10. Do not make any assumptions about the amount of sunlight, incandescent light, or fluorescent light that may be present at the contest.
  11. A cube of dimension 100 x 100 x 100 mm is kept in the yellow zone.
  12. The arena is divided into two sections for each team by a central wall, which will be constructed using coloured plywood (red/blue).

structure.name: Machine Specifications
structure.description:
Dimension and Fabrications:
  1. The machine should fit within a red-colored square measuring 200 x 200 mm in the figure. There are no height restrictions.
  2. The autonomous robot must be stable and capable of standing on its own at the beginning of the run when placed in the starting zone. Robots that do not meet this criterion will be disqualified.
  3. During the run, the autonomous robot can expand itself if it does not damage the arena in any way. However, the machine should not leave anything behind while tracing the path. The machine should not scratch, damage, or destroy the track or any accompanying parts of the arena.
  4. If any robot is found damaging the arena, the final decision rests at the discretion of the organizers.
  5. Teams are permitted to use pre-made sensor kits. However, they are not allowed to use Lego kits or any other similar assemblies.

    6. Power Supply and Propulsion:
    1. The machine must be entirely self-contained and should not receive any external assistance. It must not utilize an energy source that involves a combustion process.
    2. The machine must have its own on-board power source. The use of external power supplies is not permitted.
    3. The potential difference between any two points on the machine must not surpass 24V.

      4. Task:
      1. Teams are required to construct an autonomous robot capable of line following.
      2. All minimum possible paths will comprise 5 checkpoints and a finishing zone.
      3. The robot has the option to either follow the provided path or select its own route, with a preference for adhering to the given path.
      4. The task will conclude when the cube (initially positioned in the yellow zone) is relocated to the green zone located behind the opposing team's red zone.

        5. Note:
        In the subsequent rules, the action of the robot pushing the box and causing it to come to rest in the green zone is denoted as 'Destroying the Opponents Territory' The robot must refrain from causing any physical harm to the walls or the cube.

structure.name: Competition Rules
structure.description:
1. Each participating team will be granted a 2-minute dry run session on the arena.
  2. During the dry run, teams can calibrate sensors and explore the entire arena to identify the desired path.
  3. Subsequent to the dry run, robot programming is prohibited.
  4. The bot's starting procedure must be straightforward and devoid of any manual force or directional impulse.
  5. The game's duration is 5 minutes. The runtime clock initiates after 2 minutes of the dry run and concludes after 3 minutes of gameplay, even if sensor adjustments or checkpoint searches are ongoing.
  6. The match initiates from the start zone, and the operator retains the authority to abort the run at any juncture.
  7. Only a single team member, namely the operator, can enter the arena after securing approval from the organizers.
  8. The robot is permitted to push the cube only after successfully passing all checkpoints.
  9. The robot must avoid causing any physical damage to the walls or the cube.

structure.name: Check Points
structure.description:
1. As depicted, the arena will feature multiple black-coloured checkpoints.
  2. To successfully complete the arena and task, the robot must fulfill the requirement of relocating the block to the green zone. This involves navigating through a minimum of 5 checkpoints, which includes safely transferring the block and ensuring it reaches the designated green zone.
  3. A checkpoint will be deemed cleared only when the entire robot has traversed through it, signifying completion of the entire arena.

structure.name: Hand Touch
structure.description:
1. If an operator touches the robot during a run, it will be deemed a hand touch, and the robot must be placed back at the last restart or checkpoint it had crossed. (Robots can be removed after the completion of a match, such as after placing the cube.)
  2. The operator can request prior permission from the organizers to perform any number of hand touches. There is no penalty for a hand touch with prior permission; however, the robot must be returned to the start or the last checkpoint crossed.
  3. Even if a participant executes a hand touch, the clock will continue to run and will not be reset, as the robot resumes from the previous restart point.
  4. In case a robot encounters difficulties, the operator can seek permission from the judge to perform a hand touch and restart the robot from the start or the last checkpoint. If the operator touches the robot without the prior permission of the judge during run time, a deduction of 10 points will be imposed.

structure.name: Judging Criteria
structure.description:
Scoring system:
  1. Each checkpoint carries 20 points.
  2. Placing the box in the green zone carries 50 points.
  3. Maximum points = 150.
  4. In the event of a tie in scores between two teams, preference will be determined based on the following criteria in the specified sequence:
  5. The shortest time taken by robots to cross the same number of checkpoints.
  6. The fewest number of hand touches.
  7. To be decided by the organizers.

structure.name: Team Specification
structure.description:
1. Once registered, a team cannot register again, even under a different name.
  2. A team may comprise a maximum of 3 members.

structure.name: Note
structure.description:
1. Power supply will not be available during the match, but it can be provided for the purpose of battery charging.
  2. We will not provide any type of computer, software, laptop, programmer, or IC under any circumstances.
  3. No. of Prizes are subject to change based on the number of participants.
  4. The registration fee is non-refundable.
  5. Prize Money is subject to change.

rules: Teams not ready at the specified time will be automatically disqualified from the competition.
Prior to the match, the machine will undergo a safety check, and if found unsafe for other participants and spectators, it will be discarded.
The machine must not leave any marks on the floor; any robot causing damage to the arena will be immediately disqualified.
Only one team member is permitted to handle the robot.
Participants are restricted from placing anything inside the arena except for their autonomous robots.
Laptops or personal computers are prohibited near the arena. Other devices like Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc., must be turned off. Organizers have the authority to inspect these devices and their usage.
No robot is allowed to employ flammable, combustible, explosive, or potentially hazardous processes.
The time recorded by the organizers will be deemed final and used for scoring the teams. Any time measured by a contestant using other means is not acceptable for scoring.
The operator must wear socks.

events.name: ROBO WARS
events.description: Decimate your enemy because this is the survival of the fittest for your robots.
events.long_description: In this mortal combat, reach the top by being the last bot standing. Crush your opponent because only the fittest will survive.
note: No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Max 5 participants per team

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹ 299 per team.

structure.name: Event Structure
structure.description:
1. Participants have to build a single robot.
  2. Robots will be tested for dimensions and safety before each match.
  3. Violations of rules will lead to disqualification of the respective team.
  4. The winners of the qualifier matches will be declared as per the points they would have achieved in the matches.
  5. Each match will be of a duration 5 minutes, and the winner will be decided based on winning criteria.
  6. Points will be deducted in the case of multiple operators in a single match.

structure.name: Winning Criteria
structure.description:
1. A robot is declared victorious if its opponent is immobilized.
  2. A robot will be declared immobile if it cannot show linear or rotational motion of at least one foot in a time period of 30 seconds. A robot with one side of its drive train disabled will not be counted as immobilized if it can demonstrate some degree of controlled movement. In the event that both the robots remain mobile after the end of the round, then the winner will be decided subjectively. A robot that is deemed unsafe by the judges after the match has begun will be disqualified and therefore declared the loser. The match will be immediately halted, and the opponent will be awarded a win.
  3. The judges' and event head's decisions will be treated as final and binding to all.
  4. The organizers reserve the right to change any or all of the above rules as they deem fit.
  5. In the event of a match resulting in a tie, a rematch of 2 minutes will be played. If a further tie occurs, the team scoring the highest points in the first 3 minutes of the main match will be declared as the winner.
  6. Points will be given based on aggression, damage, control, and strategy. Fall in the pit.

structure.name: Aggression (3 points):
structure.description: Aggression is judged by the frequency, severity, boldness, and effectiveness of attacks deliberately initiated by the robot against its opponent. If a robot appears to have accidentally attacked an opponent, that act will not be considered Aggression.

structure.name: Control (3 points):
structure.description: Control means a robot is able to attack an opponent at its weakest point, use its weapons in the most effective way, avoid Arena Hazards, and minimize the damage caused by the opponent or its weapons.

structure.name: Damage (5 points):
structure.description: Through deliberate action, a robot, either directly or indirectly using Arena Hazards, reduces the functionality, effectiveness, or defensibility of an opponent. Damage is not considered relevant if a robot inadvertently harms itself. Also, if a pressure vessel or a rapidly spinning device on a robot fragments, any damage to the opponent will not be considered 'deliberate'.

structure.name: Strategy:
structure.description: The robot exhibits a combat plan that exploits the robot's strengths against the weaknesses of its opponent. Strategy is also defined as a robot exhibiting a deliberate defense plan that guards its weaknesses against the strengths of the opponent. Strategy can also involve using the Arena Hazards to gain an advantage.

structure.name: Disqualification:
structure.description:
• Robots intentionally damaging the wires of the opponent will be disqualified.
  • Robots intentionally and extensively damaging the arena will be disqualified.
  • If the wires of robot are cut because of its own strategy and if fail to repair within match time, then the team will be disqualified.

structure.name: Arena specifications:
structure.description:
• Arena Size: 17x 17x 8 ft
  • Operating area: 16x16 ft
  • Polycarbonate covering: 10 mm Lexan All Side
  • Floor Thickness : MS 4 mm

rules:
Dimensions and Fabrications:
  • The robot should always fit in a box of 750 mm x 750 mm x 1000 mm (l x b x h) at the start of the game. Once the game starts, the robots will be allowed to extend to any size. The external device used to control the robot or any external tank is not included in the size constraint.
  • The robot should not exceed 15 kg, including the weight of the pneumatic source or tank. If the tank is external, its weight would be considered 1.5 times its actual weight.
  • The weight of the remote controller and adapter will be excluded.

Motion of the Robot:
  • Jumping and hopping is not allowed.
  • Flying (using airfoils, helium balloons, or ornithopters) is not allowed.

Control of Robot:
  • The robot must be controlled only through wireless remote, while all power supply must be on-board.
  • Off-board power supplies are not allowed.
  • In case of wireless control, the case frequency interference with other teams will not be considered for rematch or for results.
  • There should be binding capability between transmitters and receivers and they must be able to connect between polycarbonate (10mm), Metal bars and Barriers. Only the remotes with such facility will be allowed.

Battery and Power:
  • The machine can be powered electrically Use of an IC engine in any form is not allowed. On board batteries must be sealed, immobilized-electrolyte types (such as gel cells, lithium, NiCad, NiMH, or dry cells).
  • The electric voltage between 2 points anywhere in the machine should not be more than 36 V DC at any point of time. If a team is using AC voltage in any of its parts, then the voltage should not exceed 36 V AC at any point of time as well.
  • All efforts must be made to protect battery terminals from a direct short and prevent a battery fire. Failure to do so will cause direct disqualification.
  • Special care should be taken to protect the on-board batteries.

Hydraulics:
  • A robot can use non-inflammable liquid to actuate hydraulic devices.
  • All hydraulic components on-board a robot must be securely mounted.
  • Special care must be taken while mounting the pump, accumulator, and armor to ensure that if ruptured, direct fluid streams will not escape the robot.
  • Whole hydraulic systems should be leaked. The maximum allowed pressure is 8 bars.
  • The participant must be able to indicate the used pressure with an integrated or temporarily fitted pressure gauge.

Pneumatics:
  • A robot can use pressurized non-inflammable gases to actuate pneumatic the maximum allowed outlet pressure is 8 bars. The storage tank and pressure regulators used by the teams need to be certified. Teams using pneumatics are required to produce the safety and security letters at the registration desk at the venue. Failing to do so will lead to direct disqualification.
  • Participants must be able to indicate the used pressure with an integrated or temporarily fitted pressure gauge. Also, there should be provision to check the cylinder pressure on the bot.
  • You must have a safe way of refilling the system and determining the on- board All pneumatic components on board a robot must be securely mounted. Care must be taken while mounting the pressure vessel and armor to ensure that if ruptured, it will not escape the robot. Failing to do so will lead to direct disqualification.

Weapons:
Robots can have any kind of cutters, flippers, saws, lifting devices, spinning hammers, etc. as weapons. Exceptions and Limitations for Weapons
  • Liquid projectiles.
  • Any kind of inflammable liquid
  • Flame-based weapons
  • Any kind of explosive or intentionally ignited solid or potentially ignitable solid
  • Nets, tape, glue, chains, or any other method of entanglement
  • high-power magnets or electromagnets.
  • Radio jamming, lasers, tesla coils, or any other high-voltage devices.
  • Tethered or un-tethered projectiles
  • Spinning weapons which do not come into contact with the arena at any point of time are allowed. In any case, the arena should not be damaged by any bot.

Safety Rules:
  • Special care should be taken to protect the on-board batteries and pneumatics, robot without proper protection will not be allowed to compete.
  • Robots must be activated in the arena or with the expressed consent of the event coordinators.
  • All weapons must have a safety cover on any sharp edges.
  • All participants build and operate robots at their own risk. Please take care to not hurt yourself or others when building, testing, and competing. Organizers will not be responsible for any injuries to operators or team members.
  • In the event of any disputes, the decision of the organizers and the judges will be final and binding to all.

Is on-spot participation allowed?
Who can participate in the event?
a: You can participate in any event in MindSpark, provided you can manage your own schedule.
Yes. On-spot participation is allowed.
Any college (UG)* student. You may be asked to present a valid ID card and the registration receipt.

events.name: ROBO ROYALE
events.description: Complete the given tasks and then prevent your opponent from doing theirs.
events.long_description: A match is between Red and Blue teams. It last five minutes at most. Each team has one manual robot. The team which scores maximum points will win the match.
rules:
GENERAL RULES:
  1. At each hand touch, all the blocks in touch with the robot of that team (except for the ones already deposited) will be returned to their original positions.
  2. Blocks will be placed in their original position after retrying if they were wrongly placed.
  3. A maximum of five violations are allowed; any violations after that would lead to disqualification.
  4. Any team that is not ready at the specified time will be disqualified from the competition.
  5. The robot will be checked for its safety before the match and will be discarded if found unsafe for other participants, spectators, or the arena.
  6. The name of your robot must be prominently displayed on the robot.
  7. Operators can't step onto the arena unless permitted by the judges.
  8. The AR operator must operate from outside the arena.
  9. The judge's decision shall be treated as final and binding to all.
  10. The Organisers reserve the right to change any or all of the above rules as they deem fit.
  11. Ready-made Robots are not allowed, but ready-made sensor kits are allowed.

RETRY RULES:
  1. For both robots, an unlimited number of retries will be allowed.
  2. The operator will first have to ask the judges for a hand-touch/retry and will take the hand-touch/retry only when allowed. The AR can restart from the start zone.
  3. The orientation of the robot after the hand-touch will be decided by the judges.
  4. The timer will continue to run in this period and the other team will continue.

SAFETY RULES:
  1. It is not permitted to use fire, water, or spray chemicals. This would lead to immediate disqualification of the team.
  2. Jamming of RF control signals is NOT allowed. Teams MUST inform the judges about the RF signals involved in their robot during the robot's registration and before the start of the competition.
  3. No deliberate damage must be done to the arena. The mechanism to carry objects should NOT damage them or any part of the arena. Any damage caused after prior warning has been given will lead to disqualification.
  4. The decision of the MindSpark team will be considered final in the case of any dispute.

MISCELLANEOUS:
  1. The total game field is 4060x3060 mm.
  2. The game field is surrounded by walls that are 30 mm thick and 100 mm height.
  3. The arena is symmetrically divided into two ideal parts for both the red and blue teams.
  4. All objects and arena parts will be coated with vinyl sheets in their respective colours.
  5. The thickness of all the walls is subject to change without any prior notice.
  6. The colour shades of the arena and the objects are subject to variation within acceptable limits.
  7. The dimensions of static objects in the arena may change subject to manufacturing difficulties.
  8. 5% bidirectional tolerance is applicable to all the static objects in the arena.
  9. Any changes in the arena will be communicated to participants and highlighted on the website.

structure.description: A match is between Red and Blue teams. It last five minutes at most. Each team has one manual robot. The team which scores maximum points will win the match.

structure.name: Sample images of arena
Assembly bot (AR):
structure.description: A Manual Robot of dimensions not exceeding 400mm*400mm*500mm can be controlled by a wired or wireless remote control.

structure.name: Start Zone:

structure.name: The Blocks:
structure.description: The images and dimensions of the blocks used to make the pyramid are given below.

structure.name: Sample images of the block
Ramp:
structure.description: A ramp of following dimensions is used to go towards assembly zone.

structure.name: Ring:
structure.description: Ring through which a Plastic Ball (diameter 60mm ± 5mm) is to be thrown.

structure.name: Shooting Zone:
structure.description: Zone through which robot should throw the ball.

structure.name: Flow of the game:
structure.description: The assembly bot (AR) must start from Start Zone. AR bot should proceed to pick the block (one at a time).

structure.name: Task 1 :(Building a pyramid):
structure.description: The respective team bot must pick the blocks assigned to them and assemble them in the proper order in assembly zone as shown below.

structure.name: Task 2: (Shooting)

structure.name: Ball specifications:

• Hard plastic balls
  • Diameter: 6cm
  • Weight: 70-80 gms

structure.name: NOTE:
structure.description:
1. Task 2 (Shooting) is not a mandatory task, but teams can add ball shooting mechanisms into their robots to earn more points and have an advantage in competition.
2. If a team destroys the pyramid of another team, the other team will still be awarded points for the pyramid floors they had constructed.

structure.name: Scoring
structure.description:
TASKSPOINTS
Building 1st floor50
Building 2nd floor70
Building 3rd floor100
If ball passes through ring20
If ball passes through the ring and touches other teams pyramid30
If ball passes through the ring and knocks at least onebrick off the pyramid50

structure.name: MACHINE SPECIFICATIONS:
structure.description:
Only one AR bot is allowed. The Robot can't separate into two connected by just a wire.
  1. The combined weight of the AR (including batteries and pneumatic reservoirs) should NOT exceed 10 kg.
  2. The AR should fit in a box measuring 400x400x500 mm. It should fit in the AR Start zone at the beginning of the game.
  3. The dimensions of the robot may change during the course of the game.
  4. The AR can use an on-board power supply.
  5. The cost of any damage done will have to be borne by the participants. The voltage at any point on any of the robots should not exceed 24V DC. Participants can also bring their own power supply. In this case, the maximum current and voltage limits are 5 amperes and 24 volts The voltage and current should not exceed this limit.
  6. The pressure of the pressurised non-inflammable gases in the pneumatic reservoir should not exceed 5 bars at any stage of the game.
  7. The storage tank and pressure regulators used by teams need to be certified, and teams using pneumatics are required to produce the safety and security letters at the Registration Desk at the venue. Failing to do so will lead to direct disqualification.
  8. Participants must be able to indicate the used pressure with an integrated or temporarily fitted pressure gauge. Also, there should be provision to check the cylinder pressure.
  9. You must have a safe way of refilling the system and determining the on- board.
  10. All pneumatic components on board a robot must be securely mounted. Care must be taken when mounting the pressure vessel and armour to ensure that it does not escape if ruptured.
  11. The control for the machines can be wired or wireless. In a particular match, there can be only one manual operator for the MR and one autonomous operator for the AR. In the case of wireless controls, the participants are requested to use dual channel remotes so that there are no issues of interference during the control. The remote control and wires will not be included in the machine size.
  12. The minimum length of wire extending from the robot up to the remote should be 4m The wire should always be in slashed condition.

structure.name: Elimination Round:
structure.description:
• Each team will be given a total time of 5 minutes. They have to complete the task and score the maximum points during this round.
  • The top 8 teams will qualify for the next round.
  • The score of the team from the elimination round will not be considered in the next round.

structure.name: Knock-Out Round:
structure.description:
The knock-out round will start with the top 8 teams. Each match will last a maximum of 5 minutes.

events.name: UTOPIA
events.description: Envision an ideal city keeping in mind various smart solutions, sustainable measures and inclusion of people.
events.long_description:
Our country, inhabited by over 1.3 billion people, is undergoing a massive transition from rural to urban character. India is urbanizing rapidly offering great opportunities to build a new nation, while facing challenges in sustainable urban growth. It is a huge task to manage increasing population pressure on existing urban areas and to provide good quality of life to the residents. UTOPIA gives you a chance to explore your abilities to find solutions to city problems. UTOPIA is a platform for the young generation to give a future development plan for a given problem in an innovative manner.
ELABORATION OF THE THEME:
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), about 15% of the world's population lives with some form of disability. The number of persons with disabilities is increasing due to medical developments, the rise of an aging population, and the spread of chronic diseases. Barriers to full social and economic inclusion of persons with disabilities include inaccessible physical environments and transportation, the unavailability of assistive devices and technologies, non-adapted means of communication, gaps in service delivery, and discriminatory prejudice and stigma in society. As public transport systems reduce or stop services due to COVID-19, persons with disabilities who rely on these methods for accessible transport may not be able to travel, even for basic necessities or critical medical appointments.
As Planners, Civil engineers and Architects, it is our responsibility to not only envision but to actualize spaces, cities and structures that represent inclusivity and empower the differently abled. In third world countries like India, we ought to start the paradigm shift from public spaces and facilities. The social infrastructure in these countries has been lagging behind in incorporating disable friendly designs and innovations. The way out is to start by innovating and implementing different ideas in order to determine a tried and tested way of making persons with disability feel at ease in public and private spaces and to break barriers.

events.name: ON THE ETCH
events.description: Sky is the limit only until you find the right concoction to pierce right through.
events.long_description:
On the Etch is an event which provides a platform for students to present their metallographic skills
The main objectives include:
A. To test the metallographic skills of students for sample preparation.
B. To test the logical reasoning ability of students by observation of the microstructure of metals and alloys.
C. To make students explore more about the metallic parts used in day-to-day life and in industry at a large scale and to explore their microstructural features by thinking at the Micro level.
note: If number of participants are less than 20 then only 2 winners will be selected.
If number of participants are less than 5 then only 1 winner will be selected.

Prize money is subject to change.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Maximum 2 per team.

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹99/- per team.

structure.name: Details
structure.description:
Round 1: It is a metallographic quiz - 40% weightage of total evaluation.
Round 2: Preparation of sample to obtain clear microstructure and presentation of the same, followed by small question-answer session with the judges- 60% weightage of total evaluation.

structure.name: Winning Criteria
structure.description:
Scores will be calculated in the following manner:
Total score = (40% of Round 1 score) + (60% of Round 2 score)
Top 3 Teams with the highest Total Scores will be considered as winners.

rules: Display of Microphotograph (captured on Optical microscope/SEM/TEM) during presentation is mandatory. Participants failing to produce the microphotograph may be disqualified.
Fake micrographs will lead to disqualification of the team.

The sample must be strictly prepared by the participants. It is compulsory to carry the original mounted sample (prepared sample) along with the paper presentation. Participants may be asked to show the microstructure under the microscope on the day of the event.

The sample selected for microstructural observation should be mounted by either hot or cold mounting method. Both, cross-section (radial in case of cylindrical specimen) and longitudinal section of the same sample must be mounted together. Only longitudinal section of the sample will be accepted if the sample has very thin diameter i.e., less than 5 mm.

The microphotograph captured on either Optical Microscope OR Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) OR Transmission Electron microscope (TEM) is expected to be presented with the following mandatory specifications:
  1. The magnification or scale must be burnt into the micrograph.
  2. The size of the printed microphotograph must be 200 mm 250 mm or A4 size.
  3. The composition of the sample is to be presented along with the micrograph. If participants are unable to know the composition of their specimen sampled from an unknown component, they can refer to the available research papers and literature regarding the component. If still they are unable to solve the problem, they are free to contact the event heads.
  4. The typical features (advantages, disadvantages etc.) of the concerned microstructure.
  5. Typical applications of the components having the concerned microstructure in industry.
  6. A 1 or 2-page hand-out comprising of summary of the specimen preparation to introduce it to judges in the least possible words.
  7. The mount should comprise of the sample whose micrograph is captured.

Participants are expected to prepare a sample of any failed industrial component or any other metallic spare part which is readily available and free of cost. The metal objects which are generally used by us in day-to-day life will also be accepted. Ferrous alloys will be preferred for sampling. This change has specifically been made in the competition to develop a practical approach towards sampling of specimens.

To give more clarification regarding the above-mentioned points, a small video will be released few days prior to the event which will help participants to apply the theoretical concepts about different microstructures in revealing the microstructures of the components used in practice. Date, timings, and more details about the session will be informed afterwards to the registered participants.
Micrographs are not allowed to be captured on the day of the event.

Presentation of photographs on laptops is not allowed. Only printed micrographs are allowed to be presented before the Judges. Also, they must be presented on half-imperial sheets. No files will be allowed.
Participants should carry their college ID cards as a proof of identity on the day of the event along with the receipt of registration.
Decisions made by the judges and organizers will be final and binding to all the participant teams in case of any tie.

Rules may be changed without prior intimation. Participants are expected to check the MindSpark'23 website (www.mind-spark.org) for updates. In case of any small query or doubt, feel free to ask the event heads.

events.description: With a microcontroller you can conquer the world. Prove your proficiency in digital electronics and take away the big prize
events.long_description: The objective of this event is to test the skills of students in the field of microcontroller applications and their ability to design innovative solutions to real life problems.
note: If number of participants are less than 20 then only 2 winners will be selected.
If number of participants are less than 5 then only 1 winner will be selected.
If number of participants are less than or equal to 3 then event will be cancelled.
No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.
Prize money is subject to change.

structure.name: Team
structure.description: Max 2 participants per team

structure.name: Entry Fee
structure.description: ₹ 119 per team

structure.name: Round 1:
structure.description: Written test consisting of maximum objective as well as 1/2 subjective questions (which would require assembly level language coding) making a total of 50 Questions, which would be based on the following topics: Basics of Digital Electronics, Microcontrollers: AT89C51, Basics of PIC microcontroller. Details regarding the duration of Round 1 would be disclosed at the time of the event.

structure.name: Round 2:
structure.description: Participants shortlisted from round one will be tested for their coding and logic skills. Participants will be given some problem statements wherein they have to code and perform the corresponding software simulation on the platform provided. Information/guidance regarding IDE's will be given prior to the round. Coding for this round would be done only in C or embedded C language. (IDE could be MPLAB for PIC based questions). Other details regarding the duration and rules will be disclosed at the time of event.

structure.name: Round 3:
structure.description: There will be an expert lecture on MSP430 prior to this round (for qualified candidates). Candidates will be given a problem statement based on the theme of the MindSpark'23. They have to give an optimised solution with its software and hardware implementation in a given stipulated time. They will be provided with the microcontroller MSP430 family of Texas instruments and its IDE (Code Composer Studio CCS). All the material for implementation will be provided by organisers. Internet facility will also be provided.

structure.name: Elimination Criteria
structure.description: Students will be eliminated on the basis of MCQ results, their coding and logical skills (efficiency and accuracy) and their solutions to the problem statement given in the question.

rules: The event is open for undergraduate students only.
Participants are required to give correct contact details, so as to inform them about the event updates.
Participants must bring their College ID cards and receipt of registration during reporting.
Only 'C' and embedded 'C' language can be used for round 1 and 2.
For round 1, wherever mentioned the code must be written in Assembly language.
The IDE to be used for round 3 is CCS (which will be introduced prior to the round).
The decision of the judges and the organizers will be final.
The microcontroller and other hardware will be provided by the organizers.
The organizers have the right to change the above-mentioned rules without giving any prior notice (participants are requested to check the website for updates: www.mind-spark.org).
Registration at the first day of the event will be there but preference will be given to pre-registered teams.

q: I am participating in another event in MindSpark. Can I still register for this event?
Is on-spot participation allowed?
Who can participate in the event?
Which languages can be used for programming the microcontroller?
On which interface will the implementation take place?
Will the teams have access to microcontroller datasheet and user guide during design?
a: You can participate in any event in MindSpark, provided you can manage your own schedule.
Yes. On-spot participation is allowed.
Any college (UG)* student. You may be asked to present a valid ID card and the registration receipt.
The microcontroller can be programmed with “C” language.
The design is to be implemented on breadboard.

Yes, the teams will have access to microcontroller datasheet and user guide during 2nd and 3rd round of the competition. The teams will also have access to datasheets of other required components upon request.

details.description: Our event is specifically curated to bring forth the best talents in the  ever tech evolving world, inviting dedicated tech enthusiasts to participate in a theme-based competition.

events.name: The Game of Innovations
events.description: The game of Innovations - where Tech grows Expo(nentially) is specifically curated to bring forth the best talents in the ever tech evolving world, inviting dedicated tech enthusiasts to participate in a theme-based competition.
events.long_description: The game of Innovations - where Tech grows Expo(nentially) is specifically curated to bring forth the best talents in the ever tech evolving world, inviting dedicated tech enthusiasts to participate in a theme-based competition. Participants in this event will have the opportunity to showcase their innovative projects at TechExpo, MindSpark'23 with each entry being carefully evaluated for its creativity and uniqueness. This event will provide a platform for the young tech enthusiasts to showcase their products to be viewed by college students, school students, and industry professionals alike.
rules: Any clubs associated with any college are not eligible to participate in this competition.
All teams must submit their comprehensive project ideas, including descriptions, designs, recognitions, photos, and video links in pdf format, by the 22nd of October.
The results of Round 1 will be announced on the 24th of October.
The participants who qualify for the next round will have to confirm their presence at TechExpo, MindSpark'23 by 25th October 12:00 pm.
Failure to adhere the above-mentioned rules will result in immediate disqualification.
The prize pool is subject to change.
Decision of the organizers shall be considered final and binding to all.
Rules may be changed without prior intimation. Participants are, therefore, requested to check the official MindSpark'23 website regularly for updates. (www.mind-spark.org).
note: If number of participants are less than 20 then only 2 winners will be selected.
If number of participants are less than 5 then only 1 winner will be selected.
If number of participants are less than or equal to 3 then event will be cancelled.
No. of Prizes are subject to change depending on number of participants.
Registration fee is non-refundable.
Prize money is subject to change.

structure.name: Round 1:
structure.description: Participants will be shortlisted based on the innovation and creativity demonstrated in their projects. To participate in this round, teams are required to submit detailed project ideas, including project description, designs, recognitions, photos, and video links in a pdf format.

structure.name: Round 2 (TechExpo Stall: 3 Days):
structure.description: The top contestants from Round 1 will be given the opportunity to showcase their projects at TechExpo, MindSpark'23 on 27th, 28th, 29th October 2023.

structure.name: Deadline
structure.description: Round-1: 22nd October 2023

structure.name: Winning Criteria:
structure.description: The winning project will be determined through a voting system, and a cash prize of ₹ 5000 will be awarded to the victors.
